newsitem.title: CHINA: Yuan closes down against US dollar on rate cut.
newsitem.headline: Yuan closes down against US dollar on rate cut.

text.p: The Chinese yuan closed down on Friday because of a cut in bank interest rates, at 8.3071 against the U.S dollar, from Thursday's 8.3050, on the Shanghai-based interbank foreign exchange market, traders said.
China cut deposit and lending rates by an average of 1.5 and 1.2 percentage points as from Friday, the People's Bank of China, the central bank, announced late on Thursday.
Dealers said that the cuts weakened strong pro-yuan sentiment, but their impact was less than expected.
The yuan opened down at 8.3060 and hit an intra-day high of 8.3059 early in the session.
It then fell on consolidation around 8.3070 for the rest session, touching an intra-day low of 8.3081 in the midsession.
Trading was active early in the session but dull later, with most activity at 8.3070, traders said.

"Heavy selling emerged at about 8.3060, which capped the yuan's rise," said one dealer. "The rate cut was expected to reduce strong demand for the yuan in the foreign exchange market and to make it more stable."
"But the reaction was not so strong," a second dealer said. "It seems that there is now no close relationship between interest rates and the exchange rate in China."
Dealers expect the yuan to be stable around 8.3070 early next week.
The yuan ended little changed at 7.6625 from 7.6600 against 100 Japanese yen and down at 1.0745 from 1.0730 against the Hong Kong dollar.
